data.text: Tire Pressure for Gravel Touring?

Tires? what pressure do you run? went for a ride and any thing loose I would washout and sink down and lose traction. I started at 42 psi then dropped to 30psi was scared to go any lower. which did help. I have the stock bontrager 700x40 GR1 tubeless with maybe a bit more sealant then neededü§£ops I ride mtb tubeless. thinking maybe these I got for spares would work better 700x45. still super new to gravel coming from mtb. I did road racing 12 years ago with 700x25c with tubes and like 80-100 psi but those days are over not looking back.ü§£
I run tubeless 700x40 maxxis receptor with around 25-30 psi. 80 percent road riding
data.author: Billy Dickman

data.text: oh wow lower then I thought
data.author: Ed Wildman

data.text: I run low 30s here in Kansas

data.text: It depends on weight, bike weight, and tire... And if tube or tubeless. Without all those info pieces any number is meaningless. That said, my tires are 622-50 tubeless set up. Combined bike and my weight is 100kg... I run the back tire between 30-32, front 28-30. Could do less I guess, but that is what I do.
data.author: Andre Velloso

data.text: yep, rider weight is the largest variable here.
data.author: Jason Geer

data.text: very true! tubeless 700x40 weight is around 150 lbs
data.author: Ed Wildman

John Lasne

data.text: I run my 2.3‚Äù tires on my MTB at 45-50 and only once had to lower them down to 30 for a long stretch of deep sand. I have been told more than once thet is too high a pressure, but it works for me on paved, hard pack, gravel, and dirt. The tires and not very aggressive but I always make the climb fine. On most downhill I like to do a lot of my turns with the rear brake so it works great. Anyway, that is my story and I am sticking with it.
data.author: John Lasne

data.text: yeah thats higher then I run on my mtb I run from 17-22psi on 2.6 or 2.8 tires

data.text: if I was just in extreme off road it would be different but my rides cover all type of terrain, and you are riding bigger tires

data.author: Manny Illana

data.text: I have a set of EMP‚Äôs on my 700c rims. I‚Äôm 170lbs and run mine around 27. 30 feels too rough and 25 too mushy. I ride blacktop, smooth dirt and chunky all at the same pressure. I have about 1500 miles on them and no flats of any kind. I‚Äôm trying panaracers on the 650b‚Äôs but so far prefer Donnelys
data.author: Kevin Pedersen

data.text: I am hearing the panaracers are good but didnt have anything wider then 38c at my shop so I got these
data.author: Ed Wildman

data.text: they are 48mm mounted on a wider 650b rim. I ran the same 27lbs in them and expected a softer rider. The EMP‚Äôs on a narrower alloy rim gave me a more supple feel. Maybe I need to go down in pressure on the gravel kings to get the same ride. They are a recent upgrade. My plan is to run a narrower set of tires on the 700‚Äôs. My girlfriend has been eyeing up my EMP‚Äôs for her bike.
data.author: Kevin Pedersen

data.text: I used to race on 23mm tubulars as well. 120psi for me. but I was 165lbs as a junior and 175 later plus 20lbs for the bike (and I'm 25 more than that today, but I'm tall) . in comparison, on my mountainbike, I've always been happy with about 60psi on 26x1.95", so quite similar to 50mm wide. but I choose tires based on terrain. there's no one-tire-for-all-terrains, even if they call it all-terrain. lol I've gone up mountains (literally, like steep motorcycle trails in summer that go up downhill ski hills) and haven't had issues with grip. just choose the right tire for the terrain.
data.author: Timm Sima

data.text: oh for sure I am around 150 lbs geared up
data.author: Ed Wildman

data.text: those higher pressures were to compensate for much smaller volume. run the lowest you can go without excess tyre deformation / squirming or worse burping. nothing wrong with extra sealant. apart from the weight / volume how you ride is a factor. I vary by almost 10psi if I am doing a route for comfort or speed, as you need slightly higher pressure to rail corners (but not so much you lose grip). If 30 still sees a well shaped tyre and no squirm you can go lower!
data.author: Christian Borrman

data.text: thanks

data.author: T.j. Oehmen

data.text: nice I havent looked into continental tires yet
data.author: Ed Wildman

data.text: , they are the only tires I run anymore. I have had issues with every other brand, (except WTB). I run TerraTrail's, CrossKings and Gator HardShell's on my gravel bike, CrossKing's, TrailKings and MountainKings on my XC bike, Argotol, Kryptotal, Der Kaiser and Der Baron on my enduro bike and RideTour and Sprinters on my road bikes.
data.author: T.j. Oehmen

data.text: I will check them out! I have been playing with maxxis on my MTB's
data.author: Ed Wildman

data.text: , I started with Maxxis. Went to my LBS and he did not have the tires I was looking for and suggested MountainKings. They had so much more grip than the Assegai's that I had been running, so I started doing some research and realized that almost all the top teams and riders run Continental, from Atherton and Pivot Factory Racing to Brendon Fairclough, Matt Jones and Sam Pilgrim, and I can see why. The tires are made with a slightly smaller ID, making it a little harder to get on the rim but nearly impossible to burp. The Black Chili compound is like gluing yourself to the trail. My daughter and I just ran an enduro up a the top of the UP in Michigan, and it was a rainy weekend. All the riders were complaining about how slippery it was, but we did not slip once, no matter how wet the roots or rocks were. Add in the fact that it was her first time ever going down a mountain, the tires made a huge difference.
data.author: T.j. Oehmen
